[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Vocals]] | genre = [[Chicago blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[singing|singer]] | years_active = Late 1950s–2010 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Little Smokey Smothers''' (January 2, 1939{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p168507/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Little Smokey Smothers |author=Dahl, Bill |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=March 3, 2010}} – November 20, 2010) was an [[African American]], [[Chicago blues]] [[guitarist]] and [[singing|singer]]. His elder brother, Otis (died 1993), was known as the bluesman [[Otis "Big Smokey" Smothers]], with whom he was sometimes confused. ==Biography== '''Albert Abraham "Abe" Smothers''' was born in [[Tchula, Mississippi|Tchula]], [[Mississippi]], learned guitar at the age of 15, and relocated to [[Chicago]] two years later.{{cite web |url=http://www.centerstagechicago.com/music/whoswho/LittleSmokeySmothers.html|title=Little Smokey Smothers|author= |publisher=Centerstagechicago.com |accessdate=March 3, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mswritersandmusicians.com/musicians/albert-smothers.html|title=Albert "Little Smokey" Smothers|author= |publisher=Mississippi Writers & Musicians |accessdate=March 3, 2010}} He soon appeared on stage playing alongside Arthur “Big Boy” Spires, [[Magic Sam]], [[Otis Rush]] and [[Lazy Bill Lucas]]. In 1958 he joined up with [[Howlin' Wolf]], and played on Wolf's recording session for [[Chess Records]] the following year. Tracks Smothers contributed to included "I've Been Abused," "Howlin' for My Darling," and "Mr. Airplane Man." In 1961 he founded Little Smokey Smothers and the Pipeplayers. He later met [[Paul Butterfield]] and became a founding member of the Paul Butterfield Blues Band. He was replaced in the band by [[Elvin Bishop]], but developed a friendship that lasted a lifetime. Throughout the 1960s Smothers appeared with [[Buddy Guy]], [[James Cotton]], [[Earl Hooker]], and [[Junior Wells]]. Musical opportunities dried up in the 1970s, and Smothers worked in [[construction]]. He recorded again, after several years break, in 1979 as part of Mojo Buford's ''Chicago Blues Summit'' album.Dick Shurman & Bruce Iglauer, Obituary in ''[[Juke Blues]]'' no.70, 2010, p.60 He re-appeared in the 1980s with [[The Legendary Blues Band]].[http://www.crosscut.de/eng/artists/_smothers_little_smokey.htm ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}} Their 1989 recording, ''Woke up with the Blues'', included contributions from Smothers.{{cite web|url=http://www.blues.co.nz/news/article.php?id=255 |title=Blues News: International News |publisher=Blues.co.nz |date=2000-01-02 |accessdate=2014-01-27}} In 1993, Bishop made a guest appearance on Smothers first solo album with the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] Black Magic [[record label|label]], ''Bossman! The Chicago Blues of Little Smokey Smothers''. The recording also included work from Smothers' cousin, [[Lee "Shot" Williams]]. Bishop and Smothers played at the 1993 [[Chicago Blues Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://blues.about.com/b/2010/01/11/little-smokey-smothers-benefit-cd.htm|title=Little Smokey Smothers Benefit CD |author=Gordon, Rev. Keith A. |publisher=[[About.com]] |accessdate=March 3, 2010}} Smothers had [[Cardiac surgery|open heart surgery]] in 1995, but the following year issued ''Second Time Around''. Smothers performed at the 1999 San Diego Blues Festival, and at a party for [[Mick Jagger]]'s 55th birthday. [[Alligator Records]] then issued ''That's My Partner'' (2000), a [[live album]] recorded in [[San Francisco]], which saw Smothers reunited with Bishop. Smothers also appeared at the 2000 Chicago Blues Festival.{{cite web|url=https://www.HDtracks.com/index.php?file=artistdetail&id=870 |title=Homepage | HDtracks - The World's Greatest-Sounding Music Downloads |publisher=HDtracks |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} He also featured in [[Martin Scorsese]]'s 2003 television series ''[[The Blues (film)|The Blues]]'', with excerpts from his live show. In 2006 Smothers and Bishop played live at the Ground Zero club in [[Clarksdale, Mississippi]]. Latterly Smothers experienced health problems, and had both legs [[amputation|amputated]] due to [[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]]. In 2009, Bishop compiled the [[benefit album]], ''Chicago Blues Buddies,'' incorporating recordings made by Smothers and Bishop dating back to 1992. Proceeds from the album helped to pay for Smothers' medical costs. On November 20, 2010, after a spell in a Chicago hospital, Smothers died of [[Death by natural causes|natural causes]].{{cite web |url=http://communityvoices.sites.post-gazette.com/index.php/arts-entertainment-living/blue-notes/26276-chicago-blues-guitarist-qlittle-smokeyq-smothers-dies |title=Chicago blues guitarist "Little Smokey" Smothers dies |author=White, Jim |publisher=Communityvoices.sites.post-gazatte.com|accessdate=November 23, 2010}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== *''Bossman! The Chicago Blues of Little Smokey Smothers'' (1993) - Black Magic ([[Netherlands]]) *''Second Time Around'' (1996) - Crosscut ([[Germany]]) *''Chicago Blues Buddies'' (2009) - Black Derby{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/little-smokey-smothers-mn0000264732/discography |title=Little Smokey Smothers | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1939-01-02 |accessdate=2014-01-27}} ===Other appearances=== *''Woke up with the Blues'' (1989) - [[Ichiban Records|Ichiban]] - [[The Legendary Blues Band]] *''Cold Shot'' (1995) - Black Magic - [[Lee "Shot" Williams]] *''That's My Partner'' (2000) - [[Alligator Records|Alligator]] - [[Elvin Bishop]] *''Chicago Blues Summit'' (2002) - [[P-Vine Records|P-Vine]] - [[George "Mojo" Buford]] ==See also== *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.chicagobluesguide.com/features/elvin-smokey/elvin-smokey-page.html Chicagobluesguide feature] *[http://www.backstagegallery.com/artist/LittleSmokeySmothers.html Photographs at Backstagegallery.com] {{Authority control|VIAF=56159856}} {{Persondata | NAME = Smothers, Little Smokey | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Smothers, Albert Abraham | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American musician | DATE OF BIRTH = January 2, 1939 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Tchula, Mississippi|Tchula]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = November 20, 2010 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Smothers, Little Smokey}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Blues musicians from Mississippi]] [[Category:Chicago blues musicians]] [[Category:People from Holmes County, Mississippi]]
